comments.content: That's why hiking is not good for you. Jumping  üåµ , rattle snakes,  ü¶Ç . Honestly the couch is good to me.

They don't JUMP! AHHHHHH why does everything say they jump?! I moved to AZ and was so excited to witness the famous "jumping cactus" but all I found were stupid videos of stupid people brushing up against them.

I have and it was only 3 itty bitty spines that stuck me and those hooks are no joke. Hurt like hell getting them out and I had a nice sore bruise. I can't imagine getting stuck by more.  üò± üò± üò± üò± üò±

I think they call them "jumping" because the can reach way more than you think. I merely pointed at one from about 15 feet away and my hand was instantly disabled with a bunch of spines in it. I couldn't drive and had to ask someone to buy scissors so I could start the two-hour removal process. I stay miles away from them now  :-)

Best thing I found to remove a cholla needle is a needle nose plyers which I always carried with me wgen I went back in the desert, I have had the wind blow some clumps on me and the horse as they can stick like glue, they are bad but they are a part of the desert !

They forgot to say when at a desert party getting drunk be very careful I've jumped a mile and a half away from the party trying to jump away from one plant and land on another. Was not a fun time it took a month before I felt they were all gone. That should be reason number one.
been there.  fell through a large one trail riding years ago.  I looked like a porcupine and it took a bottle of tequila and a 3 hour bath as i recall.
I stepped on one while we were on a camping trip to Ventana Cave near the TO reservation near Tucson.   I was about 5 years old and mom spent the afternoon picking chills from my foot. Ouch.

Really hurts! When I was a young girl I was riding on the shoulders of a family member coming down a mountain, he stumbled and fell, throwing me into a large jumping cactus. Needless to say I was covered with thrones everywhere!  üåµ   üò¨
The best way to remove a cholla blub is with a match light the needles on fire and then pull the spines out one by one. The chance of rolling the bulb and getting more spines is reduced this way.

I hate jumping Cholla my cat got tangled up with one like to have never got it out from under her leg I've gotten stuck by them so I dug it up put it in the trash I'll never have another one in my yard

Head's up, AZ visitors!  Early in my Sonoran Desert hiking adventures, I had one catch on my hiking boot, which transferred to the calf of my leg.  Thank goodness I was with experienced hikers carrying first aid kits with all of the necessities.

As a Az Native I have had my thrills with this stuff.. Stay away!! Don't hike thru patches of it as it will stick in shoe and end up in back of opposite calf!! No fun in hands, feet, face, legs! No fun anywhere and the pain does not end when removed.  üòñ

That happenes to me once...i was hiking with one of my cousins and i saw this cactus, and i stared at it, I just wanted to get a feel of the tip of the thorns and i reached to it and bearly touched it when it jumped. I thought i was crazy for what it just did i was amazed, as much that i didnt feel the pain, I let it hang so my cuzin could believe me it had jumped lol

Thanks for the advice - of course it comes way too late. I had these in my yard at a house I lived in . They came at us from many directions. OUCH - painful & very difficult to get out of skin, clothes, hair , animals , etc. Found out they were growing in the eaves troughs !!
Had one catch a ride hone couple of years ago. Grew up near my front door. Had to cut it down started attacking people coming to my house. They are weird
Gloria Ann Cota  this is what happened to Gemma. I was watching her walk and was right beside her, I swear it came out of nowhere.

They jump towards the heat of your body.  My husband keeps pliers handy when we are out in the dessert.  Nancy Parker , I have never experienced it first hand but one did get our dog years ago. Had to use the pliers

Had a dead and dry piece that was about a foot long get flung up into my calf by my Mt bike.  Let's just say I'd MUCH rather have a fresh green piece stuck in me. At least when it's fresh, it comes out in one piece and doesn't disintegrate.
Got into one as a child, following daddy as he hunted rabbits(thousands of jackrabbits in those days!). Kinda ruined me for over a week so I was Real careful after That...

I'm pretty sure my neighbor had these (but maybe a foot high) lining the front of his yard right by the sidewalk. Whatever they were, they were not fun when I fell off my bike and fell smack into one of them.

Yes, it went threw my jeans and stuck to my right calf. My dog sparky, had one stuck to his face and got some stuck on his tongue. Know that's got to be one of the worst places to get a jumping cactus stuck to you. They hook into you and a hard to pull out.
When I was in elementary school I had one on these "jump" at me and get stuck in my foot through my shoe, fortunately some high school kids came by and a girl used her comb to remove it!

Cliff backed into one and had them on his lower leg, took forever to get out,so I took some hot wax and  took them out all at once, He screamed bloody murder and swears he saw a smile on my face!!! LOL
Monica Reynoso  ask dad if he remembers when I got a bunch of these stuck on me when I was little. I think we were with grandma by tia velias house  üòÇ üåµ

Always carry a pocket comb for big pieces but I found what works good for a bunch of needles is duck tape put it over the area then rip it off seems to catch those little needles and yes body hairs too

I was out riding with my boyfriend and his family and my quad kicked up a jumping cholla and it stuck into my side under my armpit  üòñ  I had a helmet on so I had no idea what had just happened. It hurts so bad  üò≠
"A piece will break off and fly at your body."  Thanks abc for spreading falsehoods.  It's a plant.  It does not throw pieces at you, they just easily come off.

They "jump" because they are drawn to moisture. So if you get near one, they will reach for the water. You can pour water near one and they will literally fall off their bush and go for the water. Weird!
Yes,  I had a few in my hand and all a sudden the hooks came.  Had to use a wooden spoon to hold them to pull my hand off them.  We thought they looked neat and was trying to keep them.  Big mistake.
Always carried a fine tooth comb when I hiked. Easy way to get them out quickly.  Also planted them around the edge of our fence. Arizona security.

I've fallen into many cacti while hiking, biking, and having seizures. Even with the thorns in. But all-in-all Arizona still a great place to be. Even with all these crazy cacti here period LOL

comments.content: Not only did I have one, but it was on  a "party" line. If someone on my line was talking, I had to wait till they were done to make my call. (We were able to hear both sides of their conversation.)  We had to pay extra to have a line no one else used.
Had one in our kitchen. The stupid cord use to get tangled up all the time. When I was a teenager we were allowed 1 call a night, 3 minutes a call. That really cramped my social life.

Ours was black. The phone company (which was Bell...the only existing phone company) had to come & install the black dial phone in the wall permanently & couldn't be moved room to room like now. Phone charge was about $6.00 per month. How things have changed!!!

description: Neill McNeill WGHP FOX 8 As we head into the Memorial Day Weekend I thought it appropriate to re-post this video from one year ago. It features my friend, U.S. Marine, and retired Greensboro Firefighter/Assistant Chief Skip Nix standing in uniform along West Wendover Avenue. Of all the videos I've posted over the last year, this one got the most views. If you haven't seen it, it's worth a few minutes of your time! This piece features the work of  FOX8 Photojournalist Chris Weaver   Be sure to click on and check out  his page to see more fine photojournalism like this! Skip Nix

comments.content: Thank god those rollers days are no longer here! I used to wear them in bed, went to the grocery stores with them. Also took my kids to school with them on. How embarrassing that was!
I remember the discomfort I went through trying to look good. Those rollers and picks were painful, but I suffered through it anyway!
Pins for brush hair curlers Pure torture  My hair dresser still uses them but under the dryer not overnight  :)

About 6 years ago I was in a small town on vacation.  I almost got out of the car with rollers in my hair, so I took them out and fluffed my hair with my hands.  Returning to the car, I had just gotten in when this gorgeous younger man driving a convertible approached my car.  He complimented my hair, then quietly told me I forgot a curler at the back of my head.  Lol
I use to use these with my hair rollers. Now they make great "pins" when knitting. Great for holding the edges together when sewing the seams.
Pins to go through brush rollers to hold them in your hair. I had no problem sleeping with the rollers. I loved the way my long hair looked when I would take the rollers off.
What a flashback. I slept in big pink rollers every night... it got to the point that if I didn't have them in it felt weird and I couldn't sleep...
Pins. For rollers for your hair.rememember my hair getting tangled up in them.Every Saturday evening. So be ready for church on Sunday
Yep.......remember t hem well.......slept on brush rollers for 6  years.....awful !!!  We rolled our hair so tight, even these pins couldn't get out.....
Ha ha ha...I thought they were Olive spears for my martinis LOL

The best thing was when you forgot to turn the pick around on the front one at the top and you went around all day with a red furrow dividing your forehead in two.  Anyone else remember doing this?  Lol
When I first married my husband, he wanted me to let mu harir grow..My Answer: When you wear the brush curlers an those plastic pins to bed,, I will let my hair grow.  Ended that discussion.

Yes, all though my Mother used rags to roll my hair when I was young, she would have never hurt me with those, I did that myself, (lol) even beauty shops quit using those and used a jell and rollers with clips if necessary for shorter hair!

I still use them every morning on dry hair, whIch I then spray with water and dry with the hair drier.  Takes a few minutes and my hair looks respectable again.  I have been trying to  buy more to replace some of the "bent" ones in my collection.  Have not had any success in finding them in any beauty store.  Of course, I am an old woman!!!
Curler picks...My hair dresser uses them when I get a prem to hold the curlers in place to prevent them from popping out (or come loose).

OMG! It's making my head and scalp hurt just looking at that picture! My mom and I have had just about every type and size of hair roller out there, and don't forget about the different colors! LOL! I still use the pink sponge rollers from time to time to set my curl style, just to cut down using the curling iron heat on my hair.

many uses. Brush rollers in your hair. Used in knitting to mark lines or hold seams together when sewing(colours were handy for that).Making little holes in the Christmas pudding and cake to trickling the rum or brandy in and countless other things. When finished you threw them in a bowl of hot soapy water, rinsed them and put them away safely for another day. Nothing was wasted then.
My girl friends for some reason would put a hair brush in my clove box. Along with those pins. I had three or four hair brushes in my room. I would change them out depending on who I was taking out.

Pins to secure hair rollers. No sleep if you had them in overnight though.  Happily I keep my hair short and straight these days. A quick blow dry and I'm good to go. What we ladies went through in the name of modern style all those years ago was in fact a level if self inflicted torture.

Oh my yes how I remember  those pins for the brush rollers I put in my hair every night so my hair would look good for school.   It was torture unless you could find a good sleeping position which wasn' t  always possible.  Glad those days are over.
I am so old-I never wore those but my Mom put my hair up on rags!  The next day my curls looked like a whole row of teeny little curls all around my head-but they did last for a week!

My first was not born with downs, but with other issues. I understand what it's like letting go of the dream you had for your child. Learning to acknowledge, then accept, then finally embrace your child and what life is for both of you is hard, so hard. Sometimes you have to revisit those steps as they get older and it's a process. Thank you for being brave and sharing.

description: An open letter,   To all that were at the Algonquin public pool. I am a special needs mother, my son Brandon has Down Syndrome. I never thought I would be one of those mother's that write an open letter for all to read but here I am.  Today while at the swimming pool my heart was breaking! You see NO ONE wanted to play with my son. He would go up to other kids and say " hi boy or hi girl." He is sti ... ll categorized as nonverbal and he is hard to understand but he was trying his best! Every single time the kids would either look at him weird and say nothing or just swim away.  Brandon would look back at me with a look of disappointment. Not understanding why the kids were being mean to him.  Parents, please educate your children! Tell your children that children with special needs want the same thing they do, they want to be accepted. They want to be included and treated just like every other "normal" child. They want friends that won't judge them and will just accept them as they are.   If they ask what is Down syndrome? Tell them it is a third copy of the 21st chromosome. Every person with Down Syndrome will learn to do the same thing as everyone else it just takes them longer to get there. They will need more help to there. But they WILL get there!   Secretly I hope this might go viral. Please feel free to share this on our page. Help me to spread awareness for all children with special needs just not down syndrome. They just want to be loved, accepted and included!!   See More

description: As most of you know i rarely post items about my life for all to see, however i am making an exception in this case as i feel its very important. On Sunday evening upon eating a hamburger from our grill i felt something abnormal in my burger. I tried to spit it out and tried to cough up anything that may be there. Upon eating my second bite  i felt a needle like pain in my throat. I spent 5 hours  ... in out patients and after some xrays they determined that I had a foreign like straight object in my throat. After an  IV i was sent home and they were going to try to get a surgeon in Yarmouth to extract it. Monday morning the out patients doctor called and said that i would need to go to Halifax as no one in Yarmouth had the equipment or expertise to remove. Arrived in Hfx at 12:00. The doctors were great. The young ENT doctor on call told us that he was going to be brutally honest and that he sees this all the time and that there was a one in one hundred chance of finding it. He scoped me through my nose for five minutes and was able to see it. Normally he said he would have scheduled me for surgery last night after finding it but wanted to try to remove in the exam room. Lets just say the procedure is not a fun one and would not wish it on anyone. He used a second scope and was able to extract. He told me that i was a very lucky man and that i should buy a lotto ticket. The piece he extracted was from our barbecue brush and a out one inch long. Our brush is in good shape and i hardly use it. He says he gave up his brushes 10 yrs ago because he sees this sort of thing a lot. The thing that was concerning was that he said a lot of times they cannot be found because they imbed themselves in the soft tissue of your throat and that you end up doing more damage by poking around trying to find it to remove. They end up leaving them there and you live with the discomfort. Every time i was swallowing it felt like a needle was in there. Not fun. The thing that bothered me was that if we had provided burgers to anyone else, especially our grand children it would have been worst. I do not believe a small child would have been able to go through the procedure to remove very easily at all. We went  to Costco and bought wooden scrapers for each of our kids. Here is a picture the surgeon took of my throat with the bristle. It is blown up several times of course. All this to say to my facebook friends, please consider very seriously of getting rid of your wire brushes.   See More Drew Cabe Danny Graves Nancy Tanner Roberts Abby Roberts Price

description: A few weeks ago, I bought a pair like these, "jelly" shoes for my granddaughter, McKinley. She has only worn them twice. The second time being on Tuesday when I took her to the Dr. The nurse came in and said I'll need to stick her toe for some blood. So she stuck her big toe on her left foot and left the room. I continued to play with McKinley,  (who just turned 10 months yesterday) to keep her oc ... cupied. The nurse came back in and She said I need to check her again, her lead levels are really high.  (Above 60)....(normal is below 3.3) she said by the way is she wearing Jelly shoes from Wal-Mart? I looked at the nurse a second, thinking that's a weird question. Then I said yes, why? She said Google it. There are reports that Wal-Mart jelly shoes contain lead. So we washed her right foot off and they rechecked it....it was at a 6, so the nurse said just by washing it it dropped that much but lets do her finger to make sure it's normal,  and it was below 3. There were several children over the  last few months wearing Jelly shoes from Wal-Mart that had the same results. So I threw the shoes in the trash at the Drs. Office. Then we went to Wal-Mart to see if the shoes are still in the store. They were still there, so we talked to an employee in the  shoe dept. I told him the story and he said ok I'll tell a manager. So we left, I thought I'll call Wal-Mart and speak to a manager myself just in case the employee forgets about it. I called and asked for a manager, Blake answered the call. I told him the whole story and he said I'll check into it.  I went back to Wal-Mart today and the shoes are still there.  So if you have these shoes throw them away or start to buy these shoes, DON'T!!   See More Ysa Yvette Guadalupe Karina Meza Jordan Lutz Margaret Ross Daniels

comments.content: My dad worked with intellectually disabled adults when I was younger. If I ever used the word "retarded" he would ask me, "how do you think [client] would feel if she heard you say that word?" Now that I work in the same field, that lesson has stuck wi ... See More

The word doesn't belong to the Down syndrome community, it's used to describe anything the develops slower than normal. Like fire retardant blankets used to slow the growth of fire. Down syndrome wouldn't even make up a millionth of the way retarded is applicable In the real world.

It's not a matter of being politically correct. It's about being smart enough and making a choice to use words that won't be hurtful and offensive. Compare it to people who throw out the "F" word in every sentence. Same offensive people.

Because we have freedom of speech we should not exclude words for the sake of political correctness. However..There are some words that if directed as an insult could result in a beat down and rightfully so. Polite works so much better than political correctness.

People should say whatever the hell they want. If it makes them look like obnoxious, rude a-holes so be it. If you get all triggered over their words, too bleeping bad.  The thought and speech police have no power as far as I'm concerned.

A very sweet coworker named Louie once took me aside privately to tell me how much it hurt his heart when I used the word retarded. He and his wife adopted mentally challenged kiddos. I will never forget the grace he showed me 20 years ago and I have not used this word inappropriately since that day.
This is another way to become a society that cares and I think it's time we all care. Word do hurt. So let's all stop hurting others. :(
